item.title: A Cryptography Policy Framework for Electronic Commerce: Building Canada's Information Economy and Society
Canada's Quiet Weakening of Communications Encryption
item.description: Authors: Parsons, Christopher and Israel, Tamir Published: August 2015 URL: https://citizenlab.ca/2015/08/canadas-quiet-history-of-weakening-communications-encryption/ Abstract: This article outlines some of the federal government of Canada’s successful and unsuccessful attempts to weaken encryption standards.

item.title: Canada’s New and Irresponsible Encryption Policy: How the Government of Canada’s New Policy Threatens Charter Rights, Cybersecurity, Economic Growth, and Foreign Policy
item.description: Authors: Parsons, Christopher Published: August 2019 URL: https://citizenlab.ca/2019/08/canadas-new-and-irresponsible-encryption-policy-how-the-government-of-canadas-new-policy-threatens-charter-rights-cybersecurity-economic-growth-and-foreign-policy/ Abstract: The proposed rationales for weakening encryption would result in significant loses to Canadians’ abilities to exercise their rights and freedoms.

item.title: Encryption Policy a Crowd Pleaser
item.description: Authors: Leiper, Jeff Published: November 1998 URL: http://search.proquest.com/docview/217686754?pq-origsite=summon Abstract: At a meeting earlier this year by concerned industry players, the government was told that proposed restrictions were impractical because criminals had access to offshore encryption products. Further, the wait for a concrete policy was hurting business because companies were unsure of what they’d be allowed to sell. Shipping delays were costing money, officials from companies like kyberpass Corp. insisted. At the time, officials weren’t entirely frustrated.

item.title: The Five Eyes Statement on Encryption: Things Are Seldom What They Seem
item.description: Authors: Landau, Susan Published: September 2018 URL: https://www.lawfareblog.com/five-eyes-statement-encryption-things-are-seldom-what-they-seem Abstract: Earlier this September, law enforcement officials from the Five Eyes intelligence alliance—made up of Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, and the United States—met in Australia and issued a Statement of Principles on Access to Evidence and Encryption.
